journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Use of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for gamma process

contrib-group.aff: Institut Charles Delaunay, Université de Technologie de Troyes, France

author-notes.corresp: Edith Grall-Maës, Institut Charles Delaunay, Université de Technologie de Troyes, UMR CNRS 6279 STMR, 12 rue Marie Curie, BP 2060, Troyes 10010, France. Email: edith.grall@utt.fr

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue of selected articles from ESREL 2011

abstract.p: This article deals with the use of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for comparing an observed gamma process with a reference process or for comparing two observed gamma processes. In the case of observed processes with periodic inspections, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test can be applied directly. It is pointed out that, from the power of test point of view, the length of monitoring is more important than the number of observations. In the case of observed processes with aperiodic inspections, a method for building an empirical cumulative distribution required for the test is proposed. It consists of generating equal time increment observations from the original sample thanks to the gamma bridge. A sort of the original observations for improving the power of the test is proposed. Simulations have proved the feasibility of the approach and shown that when the variance of the time increments increases, the power of the test decreases only a little. An illustrative example showing the interest of such a test for maintenance is described.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The maintenance of a technical device is a crucial point in many engineering structures and infrastructures. The aim is to increase the performance of the systems and to lower the costs of maintenance and failure. Since their introduction, the maintenance optimization models have had an important impact in maintenance decision making and the applications are numerous.1,2

The modeling of deterioration is the basis of most of the maintenance models.3,4 Usually, the rate of deterioration is modeled in terms of a time-dependent stochastic process. In order to obtain a proper model for several inspection systems, the temporal variability associated with evolution of deterioration has to be taken into account in the stochastic process. Deterioration is usually assumed to be a Markov process,5 meaning that the conditional distribution of the value of the future deterioration rate given a present value is independent on the past. Gamma processes have been satisfactorily fitted to various data, such as creep of concrete, fatigue crack growth, and thinning owing to corrosion. Since the gamma processes are parameterized, the modeling of practical examples requires statistical methods for the parameter estimation, such as the method of moments and method of maximum likelihood. The gamma deterioration process was successfully applied to model time-based preventive maintenance as well as condition-based maintenance.5 Several inspection models with different characteristics, such as periodic or aperiodic inspection, imperfect inspection, and change of deterioration mode, have been developed.

Statistical goodness of fit tests characterize the discrepancy between observed values and the values expected under a model. For example, they can be used to test the normality of a sample, to test if an observation sample follows a specified distribution, or to test whether two samples are drawn from identical distributions. Statistical goodness of fit tests have been widely studied since their introduction.6,7 Some tests are general (i.e. not for specific distributions), as the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test,6 the Cramer-von Mises test, or the Anderson-Darling test.8–10 Other tests have been developed for specific distributions, such as tests for gamma distributions.11–14 One also distinguishes tests in case of a completely specified distribution and tests in case of a distribution with a parameter vector completely or partially estimated.15–17

However, few studies deal with goodness-of-fit test for process. Some tests have been developed for the power-law process,18,19 but as far as the author knows, no test exists for the gamma process. Such a test would be of real interest to compare different deterioration processes or to decide if an observed process is fitted to a reference process with the aim of applying an optimal maintenance decision rule.

This article presents a study on the use of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for comparing an observed gamma process with a reference process or for comparing two observed gamma processes. The Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is a well-known test, for the equality of continuous, one-dimensional probability distributions and built to satisfy a error of type I. When a gamma process is inspected periodically, All the degradation increments follow the same distribution and the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test can be applied directly. The power of the test in relation to the length of monitoring and to the number of observations is assessed. In the case of aperiodic inspection, a method is proposed to process the observation data and use the test.

‘Gamma process’ and ‘Kolmogorov–Smirnov test’ provide, respectively, a brief description of the gamma process and of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test. Some results in the case of processes with equal time increments are given and commented in ‘Test for equal time increment process’. A method for testing processes with unequal time increments is proposed in ‘Test for unequal time increment process’. An ‘Illustrative example for maintenance’ shows the interest of such a test from a maintenance point of view. A dynamic maintenance decision rule is proposed. Conclusions are then given.

sec.title: Definition
sec.p: An homogeneous gamma process with shape parameter a and scale parameter b is a stochastic process {X(t)}t≥0 such that:

list-item.p: for 0≤s<t the distribution of the random variable X(t)−X(s) is the gamma distribution Γ(a(t−s),b).

sec.p: The mean and the variance of the variable X(t) are respectively given by

μ
and ν are the mean and the variance per unit time of the process. The parameters a and b can be obtained according to a=μ2ν et b=μν.

sec.title: Notations
sec.p: A gamma process sample composed of N observations can be described by a set E or equivalently by a set EΔ defined by

where ti and xi are, respectively, the inspection instants and process values that are usually the deterioration measures. The time increments are given by Δti=ti−ti−1 and the process increments by Δxi=xi−xi−1. Δxi are realizations of independent random variables ΔXi, which follow gamma distributions Γ(aΔti,b) where a and b are the parameters of the process.

sec.title: Method of moments
sec.p: Empirical estimators of expectation and variance of the random variables ΔXi using the method of moments are
and

sec.title: Method of maximum likelihood
sec.p: The likelihood function is equal to
Then a^ and b^ are determined by maximizing the log-likelihood function

sec.title: Gamma bridge
sec.p: Let us assume a gamma process {X(t)} with a and b as, respectively, the shape and scale parameters, and two available realizations X(tA) and X(tB) with tA≤tB. The gamma bridge allows to generate a realization at time t, where tA≤t≤tB, using the beta distribution.
It is based on the following property. Given two gamma random variables Z1 and Z2, such that Z1~Γ(α,θ) and Z2~Γ(β,θ), they verify the property
where β denotes the beta distribution (0,1). By taking Z1=X(t)−X(tA) and Z2=X(tB)−X(t), it follows that Z1~Γ(a(t−tA),b), Z2~Γ(a(tB−t),b) and Z1+Z2=X(tB)−X(tA). Then

The conditional distribution of X(t) given X(tA) and X(tB) can be written as X(tA)+(X(tB)−X(tA))Y. This property was used in Avramidis et al.20 to propose an algorithm for sampling discrete-time paths of a gamma process.

Since two realizations (tA,xA) and (tB,xB) are used to generate a realization at time t, where tA≤t≤tB, this property can be used as an interpolation method for gamma process. The probability density function of the generated realization for a chosen time and two given realizations is shown on Figure 1.

caption.p: Probability density function of the generated realization x(t) at t=2, in the case of (tA,xA)=(1,3), (tB,xB)=(4,6), and a=2 or a=20.

sec.title: Kolmogorov–Smirnov test
sec.p: In ‘Description of the test for distributions’ a brief description of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is given. This test is intended for comparing samples that are realizations of distributions. The application of this test for comparing samples, which are realizations of gamma processes, is introduced in ‘Use of the test for gamma process’.

sec.title: Description of the test for distributions
sec.p: The Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is a nonparametric test for the equality of continuous, one-dimensional probability distributions. It can be used to compare a sample with a reference probability distribution (one-sample test). In this case, the null hypothesis is “the sample follows the reference distribution”. Or it can be used to compare two samples (two-sample test). In this case, the null hypothesis is “the two samples follow the same distribution”.

As other statistical tests, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is based on the empirical cumulative distribution function, which is the cumulative distribution function associated with the empirical measure of a sample. The empirical distribution function FN for N independent and identically distributed observations xi is defined as
where Ixi≤x is the indicator function, equal to 1 if xi≤x and equal to 0 otherwise.

In the one-sample test, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov statistic quantifies a distance between the empirical distribution function FN of the sample of size N and the reference cumulative distribution function F. It is defined by
where supx is the supremum of the set of distances.
If F is continuous then under the null hypothesis NDN converges to a distribution, which does not depend on F. Kolmogorov studied the distribution of NDN as N tends to infinity and showed that
where L(z) is the Kolmogorov distribution given by
Smirnov6 published the table of values of L(z). An extract of this table, with values approximated at 10−2, is given by Table 1.

The distribution of NDN for small values of N was studied and tables were published. They can be found in Massey.7 In Feller,21 it is shown that for N≥36, the values given by the table of Smirnov corresponding to N→∞ provide a correct approximation.
The Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is constructed by using the critical values of the distribution of DN. The decision rule for a given first-order error α is
where DN,α is found from
In the following, α is chosen equal to 0.05, which is an usual value.

When the aim is to compare two samples, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov statistic quantifies a distance between the two empirical distribution functions F1,N1(x) and F2,N2(x) of each of the two samples of size N1 and N2. It is defined by
The value of N used for the decision rule and for the relation (5) is

sec.title: Use of the test for gamma process
sec.p: In the case of a gamma process sample with periodic inspection, the time increments are all equal: Δti=Δt for all i=1…N and the increments ΔXi are independent and identically distributed random variables with gamma distribution Γ(aΔt,b). Consequently, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test can be used directly. This case is studied in ‘Test for equal time increment process’ following.

In the case of a process sample with aperiodic inspection, the observed increments ΔXi are not identically distributed random variables. For using the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, it is required to use the given sample for building another sample with equal time increments Δt and that should be composed of identically distributed random variables with the same characteristics as the original sample. This case is studied in ‘Test for unequal time increment process’.

sec.title: Test for equal time increment process
sec.p: In this section a gamma process sample with periodic inspection is considered. The influence of the length of the monitoring and of the number of inspections on the power of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test has been studied. The observed increments were simulated using a pseudo-random number generator. Simulations have been made with three gamma processes named A, B and C, whose parameters are described in Table 2.

caption.p: Parameters of the used gamma processes: mean (μ) and variance (ν) per unit time, or scale parameter (a), and shape parameter (b).

sec.p: First, the empirical cumulative distribution function of the observed increments ΔXi has been compared with the theoretical one. An example of these distributions for processes A and B, in the case of a 100 observations sample and with Δt=1 and Δt=12 is given in Figure 2. It points out that the distance between the empirical distribution and the corresponding theoretical distribution increases with the time increment. This is easy to understand since the mean of the observed increments ΔXi is proportional to the time increment Δt and the standard deviation is proportional to Δt.

caption.p: Theoretical and empirical cumulative distributions corresponding to the processes A and B defined in Table 2 for inspection interval (a) Δt=1 and (b)Δt=12.

sec.p: Then, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test has been used to compare a gamma process sample with the reference process A described in Table 2. The experiment scheme for estimating the probability of rejecting the null hypotheses given a gamma process and a time increment Δt is the following. A sample composed of N observations was generated. Then the empirical distribution was determined in order to compute the statistic DN given by equation (4), and to reject or accept the null hypothesis in respect to the first order error α=0.05. This experiment was repeated for 10,000 samples for estimating the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis. This scheme was repeated for different values of N, different values of Δt, and samples drawn from processes A, B, and C. Results are given in Figures 3 and 4.

caption.p: Probability of rejecting null hypotheses versus number of observations for different inspection intervals Δt when a sample drawn from process A(a), B(b) or C(c) is compared with the reference process A defined in Table 2.
Probability of rejecting null hypotheses versus NΔt for different inspection intervals Δt when a sample drawn from process B is compared with the reference process A.

sec.p: As expected the estimated probability of rejecting the null hypothesis is very close to the given first-order error when the sample is drawn from process A since it is the reference gamma process. When the sample is drawn from another process, the second-order error decreases when the mean of the process goes away from the mean of the reference process (for a same variance), or when the number of observations increases, or when the time increment increases. This result is not surprising. However, it can be seen how important is the total length of monitoring (product NΔt) in comparison with the number of observations. For example, to decrease the total length from 420 with Δt=30 (i.e. N=14) to 300 by keeping the same error requires Δt=1 (i.e. N=300).

sec.title: Test for unequal time increment process
sec.p: The generated sample scheme used to obtain an equal time increment process is described. Then results of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test obtained for the one-sample case and for the two-sample case are presented.

sec.title: Generated sample scheme
sec.p: As introduced in ‘Use of the test for gamma process’, when the observed gamma process sample is composed of observations with unequal time increments, it is necessary to build a sample with equal time increments for using the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test. The proposed method for generating an observation sample with equal increments from an original sample with unequal increments consists in generating process increments thanks to the gamma bridge.

Ideally, the generation of process increments using the gamma bridge requires to know the shape parameter of the sample, since it appears in the beta distribution parameters (equation 3). However, the shape parameter of the process sample is unknown when the test is used. In a previous study,22 two solutions have been considered for the one-sample case: use aref the shape parameter value of the reference process, or use aest an estimation of the shape parameter of the sample. If the used shape parameter is not the true value, the generated process increment sample does not follow exactly the original process sample. Consequently, in order to satisfy the targeted first-order error, the parameter has to be chosen as aref. However, when the sample is not drawn from the reference process, a small decrease of the power of test arises from the gamma bridge interpolation with a parameter value not perfectly fitted to the process.

In the two-sample case, in order to ensure that the targeted first-order error is satisfied, the same shape parameter for the interpolation of each of the two processes has to be used. Then it is proposed to estimate the shape parameter using the combination of the observations of the two processes and to use this estimated value for the generation of the two process samples.
For generating, from an original sample with unequal increments EΔ={(Δti,Δxi)}i=1…N, a sample with equal increments E′Δ={(Δteq,Δx′i)}i=1…N′, the following algorithm is proposed.

sec.title: Interpolation algorithm
sec.p: For i=1…N′, with N′Δteq≤tN generate x′i as x′(iΔteq)=xinf+(xsup−xinf)y where

list-item.p:
y
is drawn from β(a(iΔteq−tinf),a(tsup−iΔteq)),

sec.p: In Grall-Maës,22 it has been noticed that the variance of the beta distribution used in the gamma bridge decreases when one of the two observations used to generate a process observation moves closer to the targeted time. Thus the more the original observations are close to the regular targeted time values, the more the error induced by the gamma bridge is small.
Then in the one-sample case, it is proposed to choose

in order to minimize the error introduced by the gamma bridge interpolation when the sample does not follow the reference gamma process. It is also proposed to sort the observations of the original sample that leads to a sample called “sorted sample”(Δti~,Δxi~)i=1…N before generating the sample with equal increments. The observations are sorted such that the cumulated time increments ti~=∑j=1iΔtj~ correspond as much as possible to the cumulated equal time increments t′i=iΔteq, and such that ti~≥t′i in order to use the gamma bridge. Thus, the following sort algorithm was used.

sec.title: Sort algorithm

list-item.p: choose (Δt1~,Δx1~)=(Δtmax,Δxmax) where max=argmax{Δti,i=1…N}and remove (Δxmax,Δtmax) from EΔ
for i=2…N, choose and remove from EΔ, (Δti~,Δxi~) such that ∑j=1iΔtj~−iΔteq is positive or null and minimal.

sec.p: As an illustration, the cumulated time increment values for an example of original sample and for the corresponding sorted sample are represented in Figure 5.

caption.p: Cumulated time increment values for an example of original sample and for the corresponding sorted sample. Time increments ~U(1,25) and Δteq=13.7.

sec.p: Consequently, in the one-sample case, the sort algorithm is applied before the interpolation algorithm. An example of cumulated process increments for a sorted sample and for the corresponding generated sample is represented on Figure 6.

caption.p: An example of cumulated process increments as a function of the cumulated time increments for a sorted sample and the corresponding generated sample. Δti~U(1,25), Δteq=13.7, and Δxi drawn from a gamma process with μ=4 and ν=5.

sec.p: In the two-sample case, the length of monitoring for the two processes may be different as well as the number of observations. It is proposed to choose

The proposed algorithm for ordering the observations can not be used, since generally the number of generated values for the equal increment sample may be different from the number in the original sample.

sec.title: One-sample case
sec.p: The scheme for generating an equal increment sample has been applied for comparing a sample drawn from a gamma process with the reference process A defined in Table 2. The probability of rejecting null hypotheses was estimated using 100,000 simulations, with N=50 and α=0.05. Unequal time increments were generated using an uniform distribution for two different mean values (13 and 6.5) and for different standard deviation values. A standard deviation equal to 0 translates equal time increments. For comparison, the probability of rejecting H0 was computed for three cases : linear interpolation on the sorted sample, gamma bridge interpolation on the original sample, and gamma bridge interpolation on the sorted sample.

Results are given in Figure 7 when the observed process follows the reference process. As expected, the targeted first-order error is satisfied when the gamma bridge is used for generating the equal increment sample, but it is not satisfied when the linear interpolation is used. In the latter case, the generated observations sample does not follow the same gamma process as the original observations owing to the interpolation. The results when the observed process does not follow the reference process are given on Figure 8. They show that the power of test decreases only a little when the standard deviation of the time increments increases. The sort sample algorithm allows to reduce this increase a little.

caption.p: Probability of rejecting null hypotheses in the case of a sample drawn from reference process A (μ=4), time increments ~U(13−τ,13+τ)– comparison of the linear interpolation with the gamma bridge, and influence of τ.

Probability of rejecting null hypotheses in the case of a sample drawn from a process with μ=4.365, compared with the reference A; comparison of the original/ordered data, and influence of τ. (a) time increments ~U(13-τ,13+τ), (b) time increments ~U(6.5-τ, 6.5+τ)

sec.title: Two-sample case
sec.p: The scheme for generating an equal increment sample has been applied for comparing two gamma process samples. The experiment was similar to the one described in ‘One-sample case’. Results are given on Figure 9 (respectively 10) when the two underlying gamma process parameter sets are the same (respectively differ).

caption.p: Probability of rejecting null hypotheses in the case of two process samples with μ1=μ2=4, time increments ~U(6.5–τ, 6.5+τ)

sec.p: In the simulation, it was chosen to generate an original sample such that the length of monitoring for each process is approximatively equal to N*6.5 or such that the number of points for each process is equal to N1=N2=N with N=100. In both cases the number of points of the equal increment generated processes is generally different from N, according to relation (7). In the first configuration, the cumulated time increments are approximatively equal to N*6.5, but not in the second one.

Figure 9 shows that the proposed method allows to reach the targeted first-order error. Figure 10 shows that the decrease of the power of test when the standard deviation of the time increments increases is a little bit more important that in the one-sample case, because the interpolation is needed for the two samples. However this decrease remains small.

caption.p: Probability of rejecting null hypotheses in the case of two process samples with different parameters: μ1=4 and μ2=4.365, time increments ~U(6.5–τ, 6.5+τ).

sec.title: Illustrative example for maintenance
sec.p: To show the interest of such a test from a maintenance point of view, an illustrative example has been developed.

A system that is subject to random failure with two modes of failures is considered. In the first mode, the failure is owing to cumulative wear that can be measured and the system fails when it degrades beyond a certain threshold level. The system deterioration can be modeled by a gamma process, whose shape parameter a and scale parameter b have been previously determined, using methods as in ‘Parameter estimation’. In the second mode, the failure is random. The hazard rate is constant, which means a failure process with no memory. Then the time of the system’s failure is characterized by an exponential distribution with a rate parameter λ. In that second mode the measure of the deterioration level is not correlated with the instant of failure.

Two types of replacement are possible: a preventive one or a corrective one. After each replacement, the system is brought back to its initial state. It is assumed that the maintenance operation has a negligible duration. When a failure occurs, it is immediately detected without inspection. The system is inspected periodically, according to an interval T.
The two maintenance policies that are appropriate in the presence of mode 1 only and mode 2 only, are reminded to serve as reference.

In the first mode, it is appropriate to replace the system preventively before failure since a measure of the degradation X(kT) is available. Then a condition-based maintenance model is used with a control-limit policy.23–25 The maintenance policy depends on two thresholds: ρP and ρC, which determine respectively a preventive and a corrective replacement, and three costs: CI, CP, and CC (with CP<CC), which are respectively the costs for each inspection, preventive, and corrective replacement. Then for mode 1, the following maintenance decision frame is adopted.

sec.title: Policy 1

list-item.p: At time t=kT
– if X(kT)<ρP the system is left unchanged,
–if ρP≤X(kT)<ρC a preventive replacement is performed,
when the system fails (i.e. X(t)≥ρC) a corrective replacement is performed.

sec.p: Let C(t) be a cumulative cost function taking into account the cost of each type of action between 0 and t

where NC(t), NP(t), and NI(t) are the number of actions (respectively inspection, preventive, and corrective replacement) between 0 and t. The asymptotic long run expected cost per unit of time EC∞ is considered as criterion for the maintenance policy assessment where
This cost can be estimated thanks to Monte-Carlo simulation.
In the second mode, since the failure process is a no memory process, the optimal maintenance policy is a corrective replacement. Then for mode 2, the following maintenance decision frame is adopted.

sec.title: Policy 2

list-item.p: When the system fails, a corrective replacement is performed.

sec.p: Consequently the expected cost per unit of time is equal to

When the mode of failure is unknown, a new policy has to be defined. It is assumed that the two modes are both possible but mutually exclusive, that is, each system belongs to one and sole failure mode. The Kolmogorov–Smirnov test allows to decide if the observed process pertains to mode 1 (hypothesis H0) or not. The test is applied for the first time when X(kT)≥ρP, corresponding to k=k0 and is repeated at most K times. That means that when mode 1 is rejected K consecutive times, the measure of the degradation is no more considered for maintenance decision making. The maintenance decision frame that is adopted is the following.

sec.title: Policy with a decision on the mode

list-item.p: If X(kT)<ρP, the system is left unchanged
if ρP≤X(kT)<ρC and mode 1 has been rejected less than K consecutive times, the system is left unchanged
if mode 1 has been rejected K consecutive times, the system is left unchanged and the measure X(kT) is no more done
if ρP≤X(kT)<ρC and mode 1 is accepted, a preventive replacement is performed
when the system fails, a corrective replacement is performed.

sec.p: The maintenance cost function given by equation (8) for this policy has been estimated thanks to simulation and compared with the cost for policy 1, policy 2, and the ideal policy assuming the mode is known. For the simulation, the following values have been used:

list-item.p: the ratio of failures in mode 1 and in mode 2 have been taken respectively equal to 0.7 and 0.3;

T = 0 . 5
unit of time, CI=1, CP=25, and CC=50;
in mode 1, X(t) is a gamma process with a mean and a variance per unit time (μ and ν defined in equation (1)) both equal to 4;
in mode 2, X(t) is a gamma process with a mean and a variance per unit of time that follow uniform laws, between 5 and 7 for μ, and between 4 and 6 for ν;
the parameter defining the failure in mode 2 is λ=1/10 per unit of time, corresponding to a mean failure time = 10 units of time;
the threshold for the failure in mode 1 is taken equal to ρC=40, corresponding to a mean failure time = 10 units of time;
the number of consecutive KS tests is K=3.

sec.p: The maintenance cost depends in addition to the threshold for the preventive replacement ρP. For policy 1, this threshold is usually a parameter to optimize for minimizing the cost. Thus, different values between 20 and 40 have been considered. The decision depends on the parameter α defining the first-order error of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test. The results of the simulation for the different parameter values that are given above and for α=5% are reported in Figure 11. The optimal couples, defining the minimal expected cost per unit of time EC∞ and the corresponding threshold on the deterioration level ρP are:

list-item.p: for only mode 1, with policy 1, EC∞=4.74 with ρP=35;
for only mode 2, with policy 2, EC∞=5;
for a mix of modes 1 and 2, with policy 1, EC∞=6.25 with ρP=36;
for a mix of modes 1 and 2, if the mode is known and policy is 1 or 2 according to the mode, EC∞=4.82 with ρP=35;
for a mix of modes 1 and 2, with the policy based on the chosen mode using the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, EC∞=5.63 with ρP=35.

caption.p: Maintenance cost as a function of the preventive replacement threshold for different modes: mode 1 (m1), mode 2 (m2), and mix of the two modes (m1&2); and for different policies: policy 1 (p1), policy 2 (p2), mix of policies 1 and 2 when the mode a priori is known (pth), and when the mode is decided (pdec).

sec.p: These results show that the use of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test allows to enhance the performance of the maintenance policy in comparison with policy 1. This performance depends on the difference between the processes that are used to decide the mode. The result by changing the interval of the uniform law for μ to [7;9] instead of [5;7] is given in Figure 12. When the processes of modes 1 and 2 are more different, the performance of the maintenance policy is increased. It has to be noticed that the performance of the policy assuming the mode is known can not be reached with the policy based on a mode decision, because the latter one requires inspections that have a no null cost.

caption.p: Maintenance cost as a function of the preventive replacement threshold for different modes and for different policies with μ in [7;9] for mode 2 instead of [5;7].

sec.p: The results for different values of α defining the first-order error of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, and for the policy based on a mode decision, are given on Figure 13. They show that the performance is almost the same for α between $5{ %}$ and $10{ %}$, so not very sensitive to this parameter.

caption.p: Maintenance cost as a function of the preventive replacement threshold for the mix of the two modes and the policy based on the mode decision, in the case of different threshold values α for the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the use of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for comparing an observed gamma process with a reference process (one-sample case) or for comparing two observed gamma processes (two-sample case) is addressed.

In the case of an observed process with equal time increments, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test can be applied directly. It has been pointed out that from the power of test point of view the total length of monitoring is more important than the number of observations.

In the case of an observed process with unequal time increments, i.e. aperiodic inspections, an interpolation method to build an equal time increment sample has been proposed. The new sample with equal time increment observations is obtained by applying the gamma bridge to the original sample. The gamma bridge interpolation uses a shape parameter value. It has been proposed to choose the value of the reference gamma process in the one-sample case, and the same value for the two processes obtained by estimation in the two-sample case. This ensures that the targeted first-order error is satisfied. However, when the sample is not drawn from the reference gamma process in the one-sample case, or when the underlying parameters of the two gamma processes are not the same in the two-sample case, an error owing to this shape parameter value occurs in the interpolation step. This leads to a decrease of the power of test. Simulations have shown that this decrease is small. The power of test decreases only a little when the variance of the time increments increases. A method for sorting the original observations in order to reduce slightly this decrease in the one-sample case has been proposed. A method should be developed for sorting the original observations before the gamma bridge interpolation in the two-sample case.

An illustrative example showing the interest of such a test for maintenance has been exposed. A specific dynamic maintenance policy that is based on a decision with regard to a degradation mode has been proposed.

Other applications are possible. For example, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test could be used to decide if the underlying parameters of two observed gamma processes are the same in order to combine them for improving the parameter estimation.

The problem of determining if observations fit a gamma process is a challenging problem in the area of degradation models. In this article, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test has been chosen for a first approach. The idea of using the gamma bridge can be used with other statistical tests. In particular, the use of tests specific for gamma distributions has to be studied. These tests should be more powerful. In addition, the case of unknown parameters has to be considered since usually the parameters of the gamma process are estimated.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial of not-for-profit sectors.
